Ives Aerts wrote:

> On Fri, Mar 29, 2002 at 01:37:41PM -0600, David Stagner wrote:
> 
>>If you want to test private methods directly, you must run your
>>tests as inner classes.
>>
> 
> Not entirely true.
> 
> Since JDK1.2, reflection can be used to circumvent the
> protected/private/package private access control mechanism; provided
> that the client wishing to do so has a
> ReflectPermission("suppressAccessChecks") permission.
> 
> See java.lang.class.getDeclaredMethods(),
>     java.lang.reflect.Method and
>     java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject.

Does this solve the problem, though? Even assuming you turn off access 
checks, you still need to get the Method object using reflection, wrap 
arguments into an Object[], unwrap return values, and figure out any 
exceptions the method may have thrown by reaching through the 
InvokationTargetException (i usually test for exceptions). And it 
requires turning off access control on the method in question, of course.

It still smells to me. It just changes the smell of wanting to violate 
object access controls rules to the smell of a bunch of complex 
indirection for a simple method call. Of course, one could argue that 
i'm being fundamentalist and preoccupied with methodology rather than 
JUnit. But a How without a Why is a smell too, and a horribly common 
smell in programming.
